lines.line_text: DEscend ye Nine! descend and sing;
Wake into Voice each silent String,
While in more lengthen'd Notes and slow,
The deep, majestick, solemn Organs blow.
Hark! the Numbers, soft and clear,
Now louder, and yet louder rise,
And fill with spreading Sounds the Skies;
Exulting in Triumph now swell the bold Notes,
In broken Air, trembling, the wild Musick floats;
Till, by degrees, remote and small,

stanzas.stanza_text:
DEscend ye Nine! descend and sing;
The breathing Instruments inspire,
Wake into Voice each silent String,
And sweep the sounding Lyre!
In a sadly-pleasing Strain
Let the warbling Lute complain:
Let the loud Trumpet sound,
Till the Roofs all around
The shrill Ecchos rebound:
While in more lengthen'd Notes and slow,
The deep, majestick, solemn Organs blow.
Hark! the Numbers, soft and clear,
Gently steal upon the Ear;
Now louder, and yet louder rise,
And fill with spreading Sounds the Skies;
Exulting in Triumph now swell the bold Notes,
In broken Air, trembling, the wild Musick floats;
Till, by degrees, remote and small,
The Strains decay,
And melt away
In a dying, dying Fall.

lines.line_text: By Musick, Minds an equal Temper know,
Nor swell too high, nor sink too low.
If in the Breast tumultuous Joys arise,
Musick her soft, assuasive Voice applies;
Or when the Soul is press'd with Cares
Pours Balm into the bleeding  Wounds:
Intestine War no more our  wage,
Ev'n giddy  hear away their Rage.
But when our Country's Cause provokes to Arms,
How martial Musick every Bosom warms!
So when the first bold Vessel dar'd the Seas,
High on the Stern the  rais'd his Strain,
And Men grew Heroes at the Sound,
Each Chief his sevenfold Shield display'd,
And half unsheath'd the shining Blade;
And Seas, and Rocks, and Skies rebound
To Arms, to Arms, to Arms!

stanzas.stanza_text:
But when our Country's Cause provokes to Arms,
How martial Musick every Bosom warms!
So when the first bold Vessel dar'd the Seas,
High on the Stern the  rais'd his Strain,
While  saw her kindred Trees
Descend from  to the Main.
Transported Demi-Gods stood round,
And Men grew Heroes at the Sound,
Enflam'd with Glory's Charms:
Each Chief his sevenfold Shield display'd,
And half unsheath'd the shining Blade;
And Seas, and Rocks, and Skies rebound
To Arms, to Arms, to Arms!

lines.line_text: But when thro' all th' Infernal Bounds
And nought was seen, and nought was heard
But hark! he strikes the golden Lyre;
And see! the tortur'd Ghosts respire,
The Furies sink upon their Iron Beds,
And Snakes uncurl'd hang list'ning round their Heads.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But when thro' all th' Infernal Bounds
Which flaming  surrounds,
Sad  sought his Consort lost;
Th' Inexorable Gates were barr'd,
And nought was seen, and nought was heard
Around the dreary Coast,
But dreadful Gleams,
Dismal Screams,
Fires that glow,
Shrieks of Woe,
Sullen Moans,
Hollow Groans,
And Cries of tortur'd Ghosts.
But hark! he strikes the golden Lyre;
And see! the tortur'd Ghosts respire,
See shady Forms advance!
Thy Stone, O  stands still;
rests upon his Wheel,
And the pale Spectres dance!
The Furies sink upon their Iron Beds,
And Snakes uncurl'd hang list'ning round their Heads.

lines.line_text: By the Streams that ever flow,
By the fragrant Winds that blow
By those happy Souls who dwell
By the Youths that dy'd for Love,
Oh take the Husband, or return the Wife.
And gave him back the Fair.
A Conquest how hard and how glorious?
Tho' Fate had fast bound her
Yet Musick and Love were Victorious.

stanzas.stanza_text:
By the Streams that ever flow,
By the fragrant Winds that blow
O'er th'  Flowers,
By those happy Souls who dwell
In Yellow Meads of
Or  Bowers:
By the Heroe's armed Shades
Glitt'ring thro' the gloomy Glades,
By the Youths that dy'd for Love,
Wandring in the Myrtle Grove,
Restore, restore  to Life;
Oh take the Husband, or return the Wife.
He sung, and Hell consented
To hear the Poet's Pray'r;
Stern  relented,
And gave him back the Fair.
Thus Song could prevail
O'er Death and o'er Hell,
A Conquest how hard and how glorious?
Tho' Fate had fast bound her
With  nine times round her,
Yet Musick and Love were Victorious.

lines.line_text: But soon, too soon, the Lover turns his Eyes:
Again she falls, again she dies, she dies!
How wilt thou now the fatal Sisters move?
No Crime was thine, if 'tis no Crime to love.
See, wild as the Winds, o'er the Desart he flies;
Yet ev'n in Death  he sung,
the Rocks, and hollow Mountains rung.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But soon, too soon, the Lover turns his Eyes:
Again she falls, again she dies, she dies!
How wilt thou now the fatal Sisters move?
No Crime was thine, if 'tis no Crime to love.
Now under hanging Mountains,
Beside the Falls of Fountains,
Or where  wanders,
Rolling in
All alone,
Unheard, unknown,
He makes his Moan;
And calls her Ghost
For ever, ever, ever lost!
Now with Furies surrounded,
Despairing, confounded,
He trembles, he glows,
Amidst  Snows:
See, wild as the Winds, o'er the Desart he flies;
Hark!  resounds with the  Cries 
 Ah see, he dies!
Yet ev'n in Death  he sung,
still trembled on his Tongue,
the Woods,
the Floods,
the Rocks, and hollow Mountains rung.

lines.line_text: Musick the fiercest Griefs can charm,
Musick can soften Pain to Ease,
And make Despair and Madness please:
Our Joys below it can improve,
And to her Maker's Praise confin'd the Sound.
When the full Organ joins the tuneful Quire,
The Immortal Pow'rs incline their Ear;
Born on the swelling Notes our Souls aspire,
While solemn Airs improve the sacred Fire;
And Angels lean from Heav'n to hear!
Of  now no more let Poets tell,
To bright  greater Pow'r is giv'n;
His Numbers rais'd a Shade from Hell,
Hers lift the Soul to Heav'n.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Musick the fiercest Griefs can charm,
And Fate's severest Rage disarm:
Musick can soften Pain to Ease,
And make Despair and Madness please:
Our Joys below it can improve,
And antedate the Bliss above.
This the Divine  found,
And to her Maker's Praise confin'd the Sound.
When the full Organ joins the tuneful Quire,
The Immortal Pow'rs incline their Ear;
Born on the swelling Notes our Souls aspire,
While solemn Airs improve the sacred Fire;
And Angels lean from Heav'n to hear!
Of  now no more let Poets tell,
To bright  greater Pow'r is giv'n;
His Numbers rais'd a Shade from Hell,
Hers lift the Soul to Heav'n.
